> 
> Players can ignore it if they want to. That's why it requires debugging interfaces to expose it to them.
> Doing it this way means it's easier to increase reentry hazard without the part being unnecessarily heated in non reentry situations, which is what can happen if you just settle for reducing thermal mass.

I dunno man. That strikes me as being easily corrected by reducing the heat generated from non-reentry sources to reflect that you're dealing exclusively with skin temperature rather than internal.

Would it be entirely realistic? No, but little in the game is, and while I could understand such a feature being part of a mod geared towards realism, I see little tangible benefit in it being in stock.

Also, with regards to hiding variables in the debug menu, I really don't think that helps in making the system more intuitive for players, it just hides the factors governing how it's behaving because it's rightly being perceived as too complicated to burden them with.

There's still no "why" there. Really, all I've heard so far amounts to "it's better this way!", with no explanation as to why that's the case.

And with DR, you guys were operating just fine with a single temperature value and no concept of heat for what? Multiple years there?

Not just trying to bust your chops here, as I'd really love to know why it's the case, as right now I'm staring at a mass of variables to be tweaked with no clear idea as to why they're there in the first place. I suspect they wanted a system that would behave predictably, and had a long list of criteria such as "a steep re-entry is more dangerous than a shallow one" and "a steep re-entry into a dense atmosphere is more dangerous than into a thinner atmosphere"; and that this system was the only one that fulfilled all those conditions during testing. Remember, they spent two weeks working on this, and the reason they did all this was because people were complaining that certain scenarios played out completely wrong.

I know there was an issue where unexpected behavior occurred when multiple labs were connected to the same ship; since scientists anywhere in the ship contributed to research in the lab. I wouldn't say we were operating 'just fine' with DRE prior to this. Things were not 'fine' at all. Dealing with the old system was a pain in the ass. 

It's always been an either-or proposition with DRE with regards to part heating. The new thermal system in 1.0 should have made things better, but (astoundingly) did not. (speaking here of its impact on reentries primarily). Even prior to KSP 1.0 I'd introduced a new system for heating where I knew exactly how many watts of heat were going in and things were still not heating up as fast as they should have been even with artificially elevated amounts of heat. 

With 1.0, the old arguments about 'well it's Kerbin and you're just not coming in as fast as on Earth' re-surfaced and as I was trying to work the new system into Deadly Reentry it just didn't ring true. The truth was that there was more than enough heat going into parts to that *realistically* should have vaporized them. The amount of convective heat (easily increased by GUI or by plugin) required to solve the problem would have destroyed ships very early in their launches so that wasn't an option. (sound familiar? How to increase/decrease difficulty in DRE in a manner that satisfies all and doesn't destroy launchers but still enough to make for 'deadly' reentries?). And as mentioned before, lowering thermal masses means that the impact from non-reentry heat sources. So the solution there is what... just reduce the heat contribution from those sources? You end up neutering the system because these things don't work linearly

It gets to feel less like balancing things so much as it feels like playing a game of 'whack-a-mole', that old carnival game where you whack little mechanical moles and several more moles just pop up somewhere else to take their place.

So yes, the solution is to keep track of both temperature and heating in separate places. One where convection and radiation occurs and then everywhere else. (the interior)

That's why *Deadly Reentry* got a skin system. The skin can have a separate max temperature, separate heating properties, etc. And since the skin was only a fraction of the thermal mass of the part (or not; it's configurable) it's easier to accomplish DRE's goal of destroying things on reentry. If it survives, the heat eventually dissipates or propagates through the ship where it can be ignored or used by mods to do whatever. It makes it easier to balance things.

And as you know, now stock KSP has the same system, more or less. I think there's some differences in implementation (I wasn't really much involved) but the concept is there and even the same variables that I used in DRE, just in the parts instead of part modules. (thanks guys)

None of this probably really answers your question, I'm just trying to describe to you what it was like dealing with a new system that really was a huge improvement over the old system but didn't really behave as it should have. And as Softweir says below, I think a lot of it is in just wanting things to behave predictably. Certainly that's why I took DRE where I did and why they followed suit with stock.

And as Softweir says below, I think a lot of it is in just wanting things to behave predictably. Certainly that's why I took DRE where I did and why they followed suit with stock.

I appreciate that man, and I appreciate the attempts to explain (sorry I didn't notice the response for a few days).

Unfortunately, I've had the exact opposite experience where I find the additional complications introduced by the new heat system due to separating the skin temperature (especially the additional separation of the exposed and unexposed portions in atmo) actually make it MUCH more difficult to balance and less predictable than the old pre-1.0 DR or the 1.02 heat system, and as you know, I have pretty extensive experience working with both.

I still view it as an entirely unnecessary complication to what was a system that was working very well (the 1.02 one) with a few relatively minor tweaks (mainly a global thermal mass reduction). I actually liked that one quite a bit, while finding the new one to be an overcomplicated (and quite buggy) mess that really adds nothing to the game that's perceptible to the player (well...beyond parts randomly exploding for no apparent reason). The more I work with it (and I've been doing so quite a bit since 1.03/4 came out last week), the more that impression is reinforced.

I really do appreciate the attempts to explain it, but yeah, you're right in that for now I still have no idea why any of this occurred ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
